content.introductory_text: When most people hear "Machine Learning," they picture a robot: a dependable butler or a deadly Terminator depending on who you ask. But Machine Learning is not just a futuristic fantasy, itâ€™s already here. In fact, it has been around for decades in some specialized applications, such as *Optical Character Recognition* (OCR). But the first ML application that really became mainstream, improving the lives of hundreds of millions of people, took over the world back in the 1990s: it was the *spam filter*. Not exactly a self-aware Skynet, but it does technically qualify as Machine Learning (it has actually learned so well that you seldom need to flag an email as spam anymore). It was followed by hundreds of ML applications that now quietly power hundreds of products and features that you use regularly, from better recommendations to voice search.
chapter_objectives: Clarify what Machine Learning is and why you may want to use it
Explore main regions and notable landmarks: supervised vs unsupervised learning, online vs batch learning, instance-based vs model-based learning
Look at the workflow of a typical ML project
Cover how to evaluate and fine-tune a Machine Learning system
content.note: This chapter introduces fundamental concepts and jargon. It's a high-level overview without much code.

definitions.text: Machine Learning is the science (and art) of programming computers so they can learn from data.
Field of study that gives computers the ability to learn without being explicitly programmed.
definitions.author: Arthur Samuel, 1959

definitions.text: A computer program is said to learn from experience E with respect to some task T and some performance measure P, if its performance on T, as measured by P, improves with experience E.
definitions.author: Tom Mitchell, 1997

spam_filter_example.training_set: examples the system uses to learn

content.key_concept: Simply downloading data (like Wikipedia) doesn't constitute Machine Learning without improvement on a specific task

traditional_approach.description: How to write a spam filter using traditional programming
steps: Look at what spam typically looks like (notice patterns)
Write detection algorithms for each pattern
Test program and repeat steps 1-2 until good enough
traditional_approach.limitation: Program becomes a long list of complex rules that's hard to maintain

ml_approach.description: Spam filter based on Machine Learning techniques
ml_approach.advantage: Automatically learns which words and phrases predict spam by detecting frequent patterns

adaptability_advantage.description: ML systems automatically adapt to changes
adaptability_advantage.example: If spammers change "4U" to "For U", ML filter notices the new pattern without manual intervention

complex_problems.description: ML excels at problems too complex for traditional approaches or with no known algorithm
complex_problems.example: Speech recognition - traditional pitch detection doesn't scale to thousands of words, millions of people, noisy environments, multiple languages

human_learning.description: ML can help humans learn by revealing patterns and correlations
human_learning.concept: Data mining - using ML to dig into large amounts of data to discover not immediately apparent patterns
human_learning.figure_reference: Figure 1-4: Machine Learning can help humans learn

applications: Problems requiring lots of hand-tuning or long lists of rules
Complex problems with no good traditional solution
Getting insights about complex problems and large amounts of data
classification_criteria: Training with human supervision (supervised, unsupervised, semisupervised, Reinforcement Learning)
Approach to learning (instance-based vs model-based learning)
content.note: These criteria are not exclusive and can be combined

content.example: A spam filter learning on the fly using a deep neural network trained with spam/ham examples is an online, model-based, supervised learning system

supervised_learning.definition: Training data includes desired solutions called labels
supervised_learning.example_figure: Figure 1-5: A labeled training set for supervised learning

tasks.name: Classification
tasks.description: Learn to classify instances into categories
tasks.example: Spam filter classifying emails as spam or ham

tasks.name: Regression
tasks.example: Predicting car price based on features (mileage, age, brand, etc.)
tasks.historical_note: Term 'regression' comes from Francis Galton's study of height inheritance where children of tall people tended to be shorter (regression to the mean)

notes: Some regression algorithms can be used for classification and vice versa (e.g., Logistic Regression for classification)
Some neural network architectures can be unsupervised (autoencoders, restricted Boltzmann machines) or semisupervised (deep belief networks)
Attribute vs feature: attribute is data type (e.g., 'Mileage'), feature generally means attribute plus value (e.g., 'Mileage = 15,000')

unsupervised_learning.definition: Training data is unlabeled - system tries to learn without a teacher
unsupervised_learning.example_figure: Figure 1-7: An unlabeled training set for unsupervised learning

clustering_example.application: Clustering algorithm detects groups of similar visitors without being told which group they belong to
potential_findings: 40% males who love comic books reading in evening
20% young sci-fi lovers visiting on weekends
clustering_example.hierarchical_benefit: Can subdivide groups into smaller groups for better targeting
